title: Introduction

author: Boris Cizelj, Slovenian Business and Research Association (SBRA)

segmentation: We will have to of course be as efficient as possible to make the most out of this debate, which in knowledge economy network we believe, and I'm happy to recognize that during many discussions over the last two days it has been confirmed and again and again.
How important the open resource is and deduct eksar for improving and for updating the post secondary education.
Now in my short introduction, I will just post introduce the panel.
I'm happy to say that really, the Slovenian legend in deduct ex Professor Bartzen Meritage has accepted our invitation and will be sharing with us her long term experience in the area.
Have Mr Marco Selakovic who will be giving us some experiences of the universities in the United Arab Emirates.
In this domain.
We have Marco Divac from Doba faculty in Maribor professor that Eleanor standing salvage from Belgrade University and she is also very active in this domain and she will be addressing the.
Issue of subject specific deductive because we have general and of course subject specific myself.
I'm Boris Diesel and I'm chairing the knowledge economy network.
Now quickly, what are our goals?
This morning we would like to of course, first of all remind ourselves.
What are the urgent needs to respond to the changes in the in the labor market, so to say or in the structure of economy which require the education and training process is to really go along?
I think it was the Minister of Malta who was very rightly emphasizing that the speed of adjustment in the education system is not.
Adequate to the speed of changes we are we're witnessing in in real, real.
I've no let me say just two words about what knowledge economy is.
It has.
History in two stages from 2006, 2011 there was a smaller informal network connecting European regions interested in issues of knowledge.
Sorry of human capital, and in 2011 we realized that Speaking of knowledge economy you just have to look at a global perspective and that's how we decided to create and formalize this network.
The mission of the network really is to take what has been underlined over these last two days, very often in a comprehensive approach.
The issues of knowledge economy and we are.
Looking at four pillars of it education number one of course, because without creating the right skills, competence is the human capital we need.
We cannot hope to achieve anything.
Research and development.
Of course.
Innovation and finally entrepreneurship.
And we look at how all this, let's say policy domains at the same time.
Unfortunately, still very often not properly connected.
Even if you look very few countries in the world at this moment have ministris with responsibility, direct responsibility for innovation.
I can only think of six or seven of them, and that is an illustration that we are.
We are still.
Increasingly aware of the importance of knowledge economy.
But we are not organized accordingly.

We have 76 fallen associate partners and members from 19 countries and we have started earlier this year a global impact group which is now almost 5000 recipients strong to whom we sent some of our publications.
And there are two we are producing every Friday, brief.
And we are producing a monthly bulletin.
Otherwise we organize fora and workshops, dematic workshops and we are awarding.
Different organizations, including government ministries, for their achievements in this domains of knowledge economy, including the communication area, which is of course of extreme importance.
No.
The changes in the economy, of course, are so dramatic.
That I'm afraid.
To have to say that we are not fully aware of the dimensions of the changes.
What we used to talk about the three sectors of the economy.
This is not really relevant anymore if we look at The Who are the biggest players just to illustrate, Uber owns no cars and yet is the biggest provider of taxi services.
Airbnb owns no hotel, no bed but yet at global level they are now already the biggest provider of hotel services.
It is estimated that within something like 20 years, about 70 or 80% of president jobs as they are defined today will disappear.
As they say in the United States already, lawyers have difficulty getting a job why?
Well, because the Watson supercomputer can provide you in few seconds.
The answer to the questions you may have.
The working time obviously will be reduced on general, but at the same time.
But many, many people will be self-employed and we're not providing them with the skills which they need to do this role.
And of course, many people.
Again, the estimate is about half of the working population will be in the next 1520 years, engaged with activities supporting other people.
From medical health.
Well being whatever area will take.
And of course we have the responses which which are which are quite interesting to this, but they are far from sufficient.
The change is required.

Really, that we give the young people skills which would allow them flexibility because in their career they will change not only jobs they will take, they will take changes in what they are doing in terms of profession.
And therefore, of course giving them just, let's say the technical skills is not enough.

We have to give them the so called soft skills and this is also the result of a recent study of the British Association of Employers where it was confirmed that the employers expect from the young people coming from universities to work for them.
70% of importance they give to soft skills and they of course include.
Ability to work in teams.
The Times of the of the Lonely Sailor, the philosopher who came to the idea over we are able to achieve knew.
It's only through teamwork we need, of course, interdisciplinary approach, and this is also something we are not teaching our students enough.
Our our subjects are very often so conventionally defined.
There is not enough collaboration between.
Professors who are covering individual subjects.

And of course we are not giving enough emphasis to methodology because if people have the methodology, if they have analytical skills and in particular predictive analytics, it will be very difficult for them to adapt and prepare for the next step in their working career.

Now I just wish to give this quote from from the recently deceased famous futurologist Alvin Toffler, who said that illiterate in this century will not be the people who cannot read and write, but those unable to learn and unlearn forget what they have learned and learn something new instead.
Of course, this is extremely important.
Now we have.

We have seen in the document which was distributed yesterday about the efforts which trying to help us to find a way through the big jungle of the existing open education resources and the Global Open Library idea is certainly very, very important.
There are of course already some steps undertaking in this direction.
And hopefully the.
The Banner initiative will be operational within a year and a half or two years, which would certainly help.
I could not resist just in three words.
Summarize what what?
Prominent better just from the Gutenberg University in Sweden, as emphasized when we talk of the duck ticks.
He is using the terminology of deductive reasoning, which means that in the start you approach the task of presenting certain problematic to the students from the deductible POV.

And of course, that means that you are appreciating the teaching other what he says, so the other is not just a passive student whom you are passing on some knowledge, but it's a partner in the process through which both can learn.
And of course honest, intelligent professors will always say yes.
I have learned something from this discussion, colleagues and playing.
A high authority who knows everything and students being just the the object of the learning process, is of course completely outdated and wrong.
Now to conclude, let me just give a few recommendations who come?
Out of business activities that we are involved in in the Ken Network, first of all, it's a responsibility of the universities to really select very carefully people whom they employ.
Every good expert is not necessarily a good professor, and this unfortunately many University professors still don't recognize.
And the student marks for professors.
For example, in many universities there they're taking as a formality, but I have and I have to quote it from high leader of a rather big University.
Who said yes, we have them.
But this this this.
This marks are really not objective.
Come on, we are talking of student centered learning and we are saying that students mark or professors are not objective.
This is not serious.
Of course, research is very important, but.
The primary function of the arrested, of course, is teaching.
It is very important to encourage universities what has been done on the other side of the Atlantic.
Dividing the function of academic leadership and management.
If that is not done properly, then of course the results cannot be optimal.
Networking with best universities this is not a problem nowadays.

A few clicks away we can reach what the best are doing and Harvard University, for example, has learned and understood that very well, so all of their material is completely open and free, inaccessible.
So let's let's take benefit of it.
But of course University have to organize deductive training.
It doesn't come just by itself.
It's not enough to just tell professors.
Please take some some guide books, take some online courses on deducting snow.
It has to be done in the German speaking countries in Europe, in the last 6 seven years they have made a tremendous effort to improve that just one example.
Hamburg University Faculty of Law, even the youngest assistant, cannot start talking to the students until he or she has received a license on jurisprudence.
Deducting's that is, I think, a very good example.
And of course, organizing conferences attending conferences simply because in this small and shrinking world we cannot afford not to know what the good are doing, what the best are introducing.
And of course, create collaboration.
The future is not away.
The future is here.
We just have to be part of it and we have to be a proactive part and contribute to it.
I wish to just tell you that a recent study of the Harvard University has shown that.
Uh, among the attendance of about 2012 thousand mock books over the last five years, almost 40% of participants were teachers.
This is a very encouraging data showing that.
Professors and teachers are aware that they have to upgrade their knowledge and skills.

Now, of course, accepting the deductive is an important important, I would say essential part of the skills of the professors is of course of utmost importance, and the open education resources are providing us with unparalleled tools and potential.
We really are.
Not just professionally, even morally obliged to benefit and take that into account and use just one one comparison.
They say that human is capable of remembering something which was presented graphically 500 times more than something that has been presented only verbally.
This just this one figure tells a lot why it is important to not to ignore the abundance of the open resources.
And of course we are.
We are.
Transforming our role from classical teachers into mentors and coaches.
I have just given you here a small fraction for your reference.
If interested of some of the different categories of open education.
Resource platforms, but these are only 48 and in one document I saw a figure.
There is only over 3300 currently registered and that of course is a jungle where it is not easy to find your way.
But let me let me stop at this point and I will now invite our colleague, professor my language to to take the floor and to give us share with us her rich experience.
In the importance of deductive and using open education resources.
